faq.q1: We're fighting gadget addiction. Won't your app make it worse?
faq.a1:
Quite the opposite. YouTube and games create addiction because they're endless and meaningless (dopamine loop). Our methodology works differently:

1. Time limit: A story or cartoon lasts 3-7 minutes. It's a complete story, after which the child calmly puts down the phone.

2. Connection to reality: After watching, the app gives a task in the real world (e.g., "Go hug mom" or "Draw your fear"). We bring the child back from the screen to life.
faq.q2: Who writes the scripts — a robot or a human? Is it really safe?
faq.a2: AI is just the "pen" we write with. But the "hand" is guided by child psychologists. All plots are built on strict SEL and CBT methodology templates. The AI cannot create anything scary or toxic as it operates within strict safety boundaries. This is 100% filtered content.
faq.q3: My child is very active (ADHD), they can't sit still for even a minute. Will this work?
faq.a3: Yes, because this is a story about THEM. A regular cartoon about Peppa Pig might bore them. But when a child sees their own face on screen and hears their own name — the "ego magic" kicks in. This holds the attention of even the most restless children and teaches them concentration.
faq.q4: Will my child's photos end up on the internet?
faq.a4: Never. We understand your concern. The photo is used for exactly 1 second — to train the neural network to create the character's face. Immediately after, the original photo is deleted from our servers. The avatar lives only in your private personal account.
faq.q5: How quickly will I see changes in behavior?
faq.a5:
Instantly: Your child will be surprised and delighted ("That's me!").

After 1 week: They'll start using words from the stories ("I'm angry like the little dragon right now").

After 1 month: You'll notice tantrums become shorter and negotiating becomes easier.

This is a cumulative effect: the more regular the stories, the faster new neural connections form.
faq.q6: Why subscribe after the free trial?
faq.a6:
The free trial lets you see your child's reaction to 3 personalized stories. After that, a subscription unlocks unlimited stories, AI voice narration, and animated cartoons.

You get a personal screenwriter, director, and psychologist. Producing one such personalized cartoon from a freelancer would cost you $100+. With us, you get an entire development program starting at just $8 for your first month.
faq.q7: How do I use the app correctly to get maximum results?
faq.a7:
We recommend turning stories into a special evening ritual. Psychologists confirm: 20 minutes before sleep, a child's brain best absorbs information and forms new neural connections.

Your ideal scenario:

1. Create closeness: Lie down and hug your child. This is time when you belong only to each other.

2. Choose Voice Magic: Want to read yourself? Turn on "Text + Music" mode. Tired? Turn on the professional narrator. Want magic? Upload a sample of your voice, and AI will narrate the story in your voice.

3. Discuss the important stuff: Right after the story, the app will offer 3 questions. This short dialogue is more important than the cartoon itself — this is where emotional intelligence develops.

4. Track growth: Every Friday, check your email. We'll send a detailed PDF report: what skills your Hero mastered this week.

criticalWindow.title: The critical window closes at age 7.
criticalWindow.subtitle: Psychologists call ages 3-6 the peak of neuroplasticity. You're not just raising a child; you're laying the "wiring" in their brain for the rest of their life.
criticalWindow.fact1Text: By age 6, neural pathways for empathy, trust, and confidence are formed. This is your only chance to influence the "factory settings" before school.
criticalWindow.fact2Text: Emotional closeness isn't bought with toys — it's built in moments of connection. When you read them therapeutic stories, you become their "safe harbor" for life.
criticalWindow.fact3Text: Today they throw tantrums because they can't manage emotions. Tomorrow these habits become character traits. Fix behavior now with gentle storytelling, so you don't have to "fix" an adult later.
criticalWindow.ctaText: Don't look back with regret. Seize the moment while they still want to listen to you.

block1.title: EQ Foundation
block1.shortDesc: Me and My Emotions — giving your child a "remote control" for their feelings
block1.whyMattersText: Young children often misbehave not out of spite, but because their brain gets "flooded" with emotions they can't name. A tantrum is a cry for help.
block1.ourGoalText: Give your child a "Remote Control" for their emotional state. We teach them to translate screaming into words and cope with anxiety without clinging to mom's skirt.
block1.month1Text: The Hero learns to recognize Joy, Sadness, Anger, and Fear. They understand: "Feeling emotions is normal, but hitting others is not allowed."
block1.month2Text: Self-control techniques for little ones. The Hero learns to "breathe like a little dragon" and take a pause to avoid throwing a tantrum in the store.
block1.month3Text: Darkness, doctors, monsters. We replace the scary thought "It's dangerous there" with action: "I'll turn on my flashlight and check."
block1.result1: Your child stops falling on the floor screaming. Instead, they come to you and say: "Mom, I'm really angry right now, let's hug."
block1.result2: Night fears and anxiety about new things fade away.

block2.title: Social Intelligence
block2.shortDesc: Me and Others — empathy + healthy boundaries without aggression
block2.challengeText: How do you teach a child to stand up for themselves without raising an aggressor? How do you teach them to share without becoming a pushover for everyone?
block2.ourGoalText: Develop empathy (kindness) while simultaneously building healthy personal boundaries. Your child learns to make friends in a healthy, balanced way.
block2.month4Text: The ability to say a firm "No" to strangers and peers. Understanding: "My body and my toys — my rules."
block2.month5Text: Prevention of childhood cruelty. The Hero learns to feel another's pain, show compassion, and care for those who are weaker.
block2.month6Text: The art of sandbox diplomacy. How do you share a shovel without fighting? How do you apologize when you're wrong?
block2.result1: Your child is safe. They won't go off with a stranger and won't let themselves be bullied.
block2.result2: They become the life of the party. Other kids are drawn to them because they know how to negotiate and empathize.

block3.title: Discipline & Will
block3.shortDesc: Me and My Actions — turning routines into games, building independence
block3.battleText: "Brush your teeth!", "Clean up your toys!", "Get dressed!" — this is exhausting and damages your relationship.
block3.ourGoalText: Activate internal motivation. We use the Positive Discipline methodology, where routine becomes a game and independence becomes a source of pride.
block3.month7Text: We transform boring tasks (sleep, hygiene, cleaning) into Hero missions. The toothbrush is a sword that kills germs!
block3.month8Text: The Hero learns to dress themselves, tie shoelaces, and help around the house. Making mistakes isn't scary — not trying is what's scary.
block3.month9Text: The hardest skill: the ability to wait for a reward (marshmallow test), sit in line, and finish what you started.
block3.result1: You stop being a "parrot" who repeats the same thing 100 times.
block3.result2: Your child initiates cleaning themselves and feels proud of being "like a grown-up." Focus develops for school readiness.

block4.title: Leadership & Character
block4.shortDesc: Me as a Person — Growth Mindset and confidence for the big world
block4.prepText: School and life require not just knowledge, but inner strength.
block4.ourGoalText: Form a Growth Mindset. Your child should know: "I can learn anything if I put in the effort." This is a vaccine against the failure complex.
block4.month10Text: The Hero falls but gets back up. We teach them to see failure not as "I'm stupid" but as experience: "I'll try again differently."
block4.month11Text: Why lying doesn't pay off. The courage to admit a mistake is a trait of a strong leader, not a weak one.
block4.month12Text: The final assembly of personality. Discovering talents, developing a positive worldview, and setting goals for the future.
block4.result1: A Leader's core is formed. Your child isn't afraid to make mistakes, is honest with you, and confident in their abilities.
block4.result2: School readiness achieved. They know how to listen, try hard, and believe in themselves.
